column1: ▪ Our twenties are w
hen we have to start creating our own sense of time
column2: our own plans about how the years ahead will unfold. It is difficult to know how to start our careers or when to start our families. It is tempting to stay distracted and keep everything at a distance. But twentysomethings who live beyond time usually aren’t happy. It’s like living in a cave where we never know what time it is or what we ought to do or why
column3: sometimes until it is too late.

column1: ▪ Most twentysomethings can’t write the last sentence of their lives
column2: but when pressed
column3: they usually can identify things they want in their thirties or forties or sixties—or things they don’t want—and work backward from there. This is how you have your own multigenerational epic with a happy ending. This is how you live your life in real time.

column1: ▪ The future isn’t written in the stars. There are no guarantees. So claim your adulthood. Be intentional. Get to work. Pick your family. Do the math. Make your own certainty. Don’t be defined by what you didn’t know or didn’t do.

▪ our biggest fear is taking the risk to be alive — the risk to be alive and express what we really are. Just being ourselves is the biggest fear of humans. We have learned to live our lives trying to satisfy other people’s demands. We have learned to live by other people’s points of view because of the fear of not being accepted and of not being good enough for someone else.
▪ We know we are not what we believe we are supposed to be and so we feel false
column2: frustrated
column3: and dishonest. We try to hide ourselves
column4: and we pretend to be what we are not. The result is that we feel unauthentic and wear social masks to keep others from noticing this. We are so afraid that somebody else will notice that we are not what we pretend to be.

column1: ▪ We judge others according to our image of perfection as well

column1: ▪ In your whole life nobody has ever abused you more than you have abused yourself. And the limit of your self-abuse is exactly the limit that you will tolerate from someone else. If someone abuses you a little more than you abuse yourself
column2: you will probably walk away from that person. But if someone abuses you a little less than you abuse yourself
column3: you will probably stay in the relationship and tolerate it endlessly.

column1: ▪ We have the need to be accepted and to be loved by others

column3: the less we will experience self-abuse. Self-abuse comes from self-rejection
column4: and self-rejection comes from having an image of what it means to be perfect and never measuring up to that ideal. Our image of perfection is the reason we reject ourselves; it is why we don’t accept ourselves the way we are
column5: and why we don’t accept others the way they are.

column1: ▪ William Worden (2011) described what he thought were the four tasks of mourning.
1. To find some acceptance in the new reality after the loss.
2. To work through the pain of grief.
3. To adjust to an environment in which that loved one is missing.
4. To find a way to keep a connection with them in a new way while also engaging in life as it is now.
